subject: New mode, HostSync added to set BMC time
commitMessage:
New mode, HostSync added to set BMC time

There are scenarios where in absence of NTP server,
BMC need to read time from host and set BMC time.
In this case we can use the new mode HostSync.
When set to this mode, BMC reads the time from host and set
the BMC time. Adding to that in case if the host time is not directly
readable via common IPMI command then a generic platform specific
implementation(platform specific data is read from entity-manager)
is done to get time from host and set BMC time.

TESTED : Built Facebook YosemiteV2 images and loaded on the
target hardware, Verified the BMC time after set the BMC time

Signed-off-by: Sumit Kumar <kumar.sumi@hcl.com>
Change-Id: I1cc9a7dab9b7cf59cd71df5b07a875d717a6940f

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1
> 
> Please put a more elaborative commit message on what is the current limitation and how this patch resolves that issue. This was the same comment I had before.

> NTP / MANUAL / Getting time from Host ( via IPMI , PLDM ) are the features we already have.

The current readme does not have the procedures for getting time from Host. Kindly let me the procedures for getting time from Host.

Patch Set 6:

> The current readme does not have the procedures for getting time from Host. Kindly let me the procedures for getting time from Host.

If the Host has to send the time _TO_ BMC or read time _from_ BMC, then IPMI and PLDM have standard commands.

Host Getting time from BMC via IPMI : GET_SEL_TIME
Host Setting time To BMC via IPMI : SET_SEL_TIME

Similarly, for PLDM, there are equivalent commands for Get and Set. Please see github.com/openbmc/pldm

https://github.com/openbmc/pldm/blob/b8baffa32c65ba43dc0c2724f2642d3d668c4c5f/libpldmresponder/bios.cpp#L105

Hopefully this is what you need. If not, please put a descriptive commit message.
Removed Code-Review-1 by Vishwanatha Subbanna <vishwa@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Patch Set 6:

This change is needed as the sel_time and get_time may not be supported by the host. especially when  a bmc with multiple hosts.in this case a platform specific interface is needed to get the time from host and updated in bmc.the platform specific implementation can be loaded from entity manager so the time manager code remains common.

currently working on to make this implementation as startup script via systemd as suggested in review comments.
Removed reviewer Jayashree Dhanapal.

We follow https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/ for commit messages which have 7 rules: 


    Separate subject from body with a blank line
    Limit the subject line to 50 characters
    Capitalize the subject line
    Do not end the subject line with a period
    Use the imperative mood in the subject line
    Wrap the body at 72 characters
    Use the body to explain what and why vs. how

Can you rewrite the subject as a 50 chars or less with a blank line after the subject and before the commit body?

Can you use your full name ?

From https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#formatting-commit-messages

"All commit messages must include a "Signed-off-by" line, which indicates that you the contributor have agreed to the Developer Certificate of Origin (see below). This line must include the full name you commonly use, often a given name and a family name or surname. (ok: Sam Samuelsson, Robert A. Heinlein; not ok: xXthorXx, Sam, RAH)"
Remove it
Ack
This function should be put in a separated file or in a separated config, because it calls IPMB that is not generic for all the machines.
Ack
This one as well
Ack
I could not find any interface defined HostSync in phosphor-dbus-interfaces. Where is it from?
Ack
This blocks the time manager's event loop for 20 seconds, you should schedule a timer to delay a function call.
Ack
The function name does not reflect what it does. Probably rename it to a more meaningful name?
Ack
Keep the empty line
Ack
Interface name can be stored in another variable and use that variable here.

I have concern on threads here.
In sdbusplus, the boost thread support is disabled specifically, and it becomes a package config. So this repo will be built without boost thread support.
If you use any feature that is related to boot thread here, you will get a runtime exception.

Are you sure the threads support is necessary here?

So users could use this repo as before without any impact, and users who need this feature could add the package config.

The log will be sent to journal, which only support metadata of CAPITAL letters, otherwise the metadata is ignored.
So you need to write like `entry("NETFN=%d,", netFn)`

dbus enumerations should not be defined as strings like this.  This proposed enumeration doesn't actually exist.  Do you have a dbus interface update?  Have the maintainers of this repository weighed in on it?

Exactly, the phosphor-dbus-interface shall be updated to add this interface.
And you should use the enum value instead of the string.

yes dbus enumeration for hostsync is available.It will be submitted as a separate patch to 
dbus interfaces repo.
And use sdbusplus's convertStringToMethod() to convert the string to enum
Ack
Remove unused includes
Ack
I do not see where to use this config, did I miss something?

It is enabled in platform specific machine layer.by default disabled for not supported 
platforms

I think we are taking an approach in most repositories that features should be enabled by default and then disabled in the Yocto recipe if they are not commonly used.  Otherwise we end up with too much dead-code in repositories that is never tested by CI.

Yup, let's enable it by default and use package config in the bitbake recipe.
Then you could add the test cases here.
Ack
The data here is not going to be changed in runtime, probably you could cache the returned values, so that is does not make so many getProperty() calls every time it is sending IPMB request.
Ack
I still do not see the unit test case for this function

Unit test was added and removed later since this code logic was enabled only when the 
"use-ipmb-host-time" feature is enabled which is disabled in all other not supported platforms by default.This caused utest build error.will add the utest again and exclude this part of the code logic away from the feature #ifdef block so that the code logic will be available even if the use-ipmb-host-time is disabled.
This is still not removed.
It's better to expect the exact unit64_t value instead of NE to 0.

Why is this a for loop?
If you have multiple ipmb addresses, and some will fail to get the host time, the try-catch should be put inside the for loop so that it could try the other ipmb addresses.
Otherwise when it throws on the first ipmb address, this function fails.
Should this be == or >=?
